comment.realname: Llyfrgell Genedlaethol Cymru  / The National Library of Wales
comment.author: 37199428@N06
comment._content: Hi Steve - thanks for your comment. We think that this picture is from between 1910-1920 (although we're not sure when exactly). Do you recognise the types of bike?

comment.author: 23747878@N00
comment._content: Alas, no, but contact The Classic Motorcycle or Classic Bike Guide, they will identify the leader, at least. www.classicmotorcycle.co.uk/ www.classicbikeguide.com/ They look newer than 1920, though, definite feel of the thirties. A great series of shots, by the way.

comment.author: 13623088@N03
comment._content: I really like these old motorcycles.  And that's a great scenic shot of the curving roads.

comment.author: 38642619@N07
comment._content:
My grandfather John Nathanial Walters was a noted cyclist from Wales. His contemporaries being Bert Andrews and Charlie Baker, British champions. He actually was the first to import Harley Davidson's into Saskatoon, Saskatchewan era 1912.  These bikes resemble many of our family photos with the exception that many of ours have sidecars.
I love it, gives me a feel of what my grandfather did whilst still in Wales.
I have the Walters Family History book published in hard bound format.
You just have to love these old images! Such a piece of history.

comment.author: 39131365@N07
comment._content: I think this photo is taken in the Elan  valley above Rhayader - above Craig Goch reservoir I think - so the track you can see in the top right is the mountain road over to Cwmystwyth.

comment.author: 74891768@N00
comment._content:
Yep, judging by the bikes and headgear, I'd hazard it's early-mid 30s, possibly late 20s. 

Very definitely not between 1910 and 1920.

comment.author: 48149026@N03
comment._content: The event took place in 1933 and the leading rider was a dutchman.
